title: What is the equation of tangent to circle x^2+y^2=25 which is inclined at an angle 30 degree with x axis? - Quora

response.answer_text: Interesting question. We'll travel a long way. Stick with me. Yesterday , I had my History and Civics board exams. I couldn't focus much on the exam because I was stuck on one problem , how could I animate the tangents to a circle of radius [math]r[/math] fixed at the origin in Desmos ? I was looking for ways to get through the problem. Fortunately , I found a way by my own before 6 P.M and could give most of my time to the exam. Here's it : The equation of the circle is , [math]x^2+y^2=r^2 \tag*{}[/math] Here comes the interesting part , I wanted to animate the radius too with the tangent as to make them perpendicular to each other at every instance. So , I let [math]a[/math] be the angle between the radius and the [math]x[/math]-axis. Then , the equation of the line of which the radius is a segment is [math]y=x\tan (a)[/math] ( since the slope is [math]\tan (a)[/math] and the [math]y[/math]-intercept is 0). Now comes the hard part. I needed to find the equation of the tangent with respect to [math]a[/math]. But , [math]m_{\text{radius}}×m_{\text{tangent}}=-1[/math]. [math]\therefore \qquad \implies m_{\text{tangent}}=-\frac1{\tan (a)}.[/math] Let the point of intersection of the circle and the radius be [math](x_1,y_1)[/math]. On solving the simultaneous equations : [math]\begin{cases} x_1^2+y_1^2=r^2 \\ y_1=\tan (a) x_1 \end{cases}[/math] We get [math](x_1,y_1)=(r\cos a,r\sin a)[/math] We know , [math]\begin{align} -\frac1{\tan (a)}=\frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} \\\implies -\frac1{\tan (a)}=\frac{y-r\sin (a)}{x-r\cos (a)} \\\implies y=\left(-\dfrac1{\tan (a)}\right)x + r\big(\cos (a) + \sin (a)\tan (a)\big) \end{align}[/math] That's it. That's our tangent there ! I had a lot of fun in getting it. The question is , how's it going to help us ? From here , we can make out the y-intercept which is needed here. It's [math]c=r\big(\cos (a) + \sin (a)\tan (a)\big)=5\left(\dfrac{\sqrt3}2+\dfrac1{2\sqrt3}\right)[/math] Hence ,the required equation should be : [math]y=\dfrac{x}{\sqrt3}+5\left(\dfrac{\sqrt3}2+\dfrac1{2\sqrt3}\right)\tag*{}[/math]

[math]x^2 + y^2 = 25[/math] Differentiate implicitly: [math]\qquad 2x + 2y \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0[/math] [math]\qquad 2y \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -2x[/math] [math]\qquad \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -\dfrac{x}{y}[/math] Set derivative [math]=[/math] slope of tangent line [math]\qquad \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \tan(30^\circ)[/math] [math]\qquad -\dfrac{x}{y} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[/math] [math]\qquad y = -\sqrt{3}\,x[/math] Plug into equation of circle and solve for [math]x[/math]: [math]\qquad x^2 + \left(-x\sqrt{3}\right)^2 = 25[/math] [math]\qquad 4x^2 = 25[/math] [math]\qquad x = \pm\dfrac{5}{2}[/math] Solve for [math]y[/math]: [math]\qquad y = -\sqrt{3} \times \pm\dfrac{5}{2}[/math] [math]\qquad y = \mp\dfrac{5\sqrt{3}}{2}[/math] Tangent line with slope [math]\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[/math] through point [math]\left(\tfrac{5}{2}, -\tfrac{5\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)[/math] [math]\qquad y + \dfrac{5\sqrt{3}}{2} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \left(x - \dfrac{5}{2}\right)[/math] [math]\qquad \sqrt{3}\,y + \dfrac{15}{2} = x - \dfrac{5}{2}[/math] [math]\qquad \boxed{\boldsymbol{x - \sqrt{3}\,y = 10}}[/math] Tangent line with slope [math]\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[/math] through point [math]\left(-\tfrac{5}{2}, \tfrac{5\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)[/math] [math]\qquad y - \dfrac{5\sqrt{3}}{2} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \left(x + \dfrac{5}{2}\right)[/math] [math]\qquad \sqrt{3}\,y - \dfrac{15}{2} = x + \dfrac{5}{2}[/math] [math]\qquad \boxed{\boldsymbol{x - \sqrt{3}\,y = -10}}[/math] Desmos graph
